author: By Tom Crewe
title: They Save Others for a Living, but Struggle to Save Themselves
description: In Adam Haslett’s “Mothers and Sons,” crisis reconnects an asylum lawyer and his estranged mother, the co-founder of a women’s retreat.
content: Three novels in, a writer is running low on secrets. We know for sure, now, what Adam Haslett likes to put down on the page. Dead men (usually fathers). Widows (usually nature-loving). The children left behind (usually siblings, one of whom grows up a gay man). Unequal gay relationships, in which one partner provides sexual favors but yearns to be looked at and kissed. Houses as sites of memory and complicated belonging. Pity, shame and loneliness. Depression or anxiety figured as a beast, lurking, prowling and pouncing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Pentagon Adds Chinese Social Media Giant to Military Blacklist
description: Tencent’s shares plunged nearly 10 percent after it was designated a military company. The Chinese battery manufacturer CATL was also added to the list.
content: The Pentagon on Monday labeled Tencent, the Chinese social media and gaming giant, as a Chinese military business operating in the United States, the latest action in an escalating series of retaliatory moves between the world’s two superpowers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Let’s Discuss: Music Playlists From The Amplifier
description: What makes a great playlist? Pop music critic Lindsay Zoladz joins us to discuss. Post your comments and questions for her here by Jan. 16.
content: Are you a music fan? How do you learn about and discover new songs and artists?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Carter Never Took to Washington. The Feeling Was Mutual.
description: Jimmy Carter was a genuine Washington outsider when he won the White House in 1976. And he remained proudly so, for better or worse.
content: Former President Jimmy Carter arrived in Washington on Tuesday to be honored in death as the city never truly honored him in life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: ‘The Pitt’ Isn’t an ‘ER’ Reboot, Despite First Appearances
description: Its creative team includes “ER” alumni, and it is a hospital drama starring Noah Wyle. But it is doing its own thing (and is sometimes very good).
content: “The Pitt,” premiering Thursday, on Max, is set in the emergency department of a Pittsburgh hospital, a noble and chaotic environment staffed by sage teachers and eager students, where monitors bleep, the bereaved weep and the waiting room gets fuller and fuller.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: In ‘Lockerbie: A Search for Truth,’ Colin Firth Wants Answers
description: A new Peacock mini-series dramatizes a father’s obsessive investigation into Britain’s worst terrorist attack: the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103.
content: When the Scottish playwright David Harrower set out to script a TV adaptation of “The Lockerbie Bombing: A Father’s Search for Justice” — Jim Swire’s skeptical book laying out who he believed was really responsible for the deadliest terrorist attack in British history — he had to ask himself: What if Swire was wrong?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: North Carolina Supreme Court May Decide a Supreme Court Election
description: Three counts show an incumbent Democrat won election to the State Supreme Court. But an unusual protest by the G.O.P. challenger could be headed to that same Republican-controlled court.
content: The Election Day vote count and two subsequent recounts all concluded that Justice Allison Riggs, the Democratic incumbent, narrowly won her race for a seat on the North Carolina Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Jean-Marie Le Pen, Rabble-Rousing Leader of French Far Right, Dies at 96
description: He ran unsuccessfully for the French presidency five times, riding waves of discontent and xenophobia as the leader of the National Front party.
content: Jean-Marie Le Pen, the founding father of France’s modern political far-right who built a half-century career on rants of barely disguised racism, antisemitism and neo-Nazi propaganda, died on Tuesday in Garches, west of Paris. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michel Helou
title: Now Is the Time to Reimagine Lebanon
description: The fall of the Syrian regime and loss of Iranian influence opens the door for the Lebanese to finally take their fate into their own hands.
content: I hadn’t been to Syria in 14 years. After the fall of President Bashar al-Assad, I couldn’t wait to make the two-hour drive from Beirut to Damascus and witness the end of this 54-year dictatorship. When I arrived five days after his ouster, I saw the elation of thousands of Syrians celebrating freedom in the largest square in Damascus and the anguished panic of those looking for missing loved ones at the infamous Sednaya prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Short of Heat and Power, a Breakaway Region Struggles Without Russian Gas
description: An energy crisis in Transnistria, a pro-Russian territory between Moldova and Ukraine, erupted on Jan. 1 when Moscow stopped supplying natural gas through a pipeline running across Ukraine.
content: After struggling without heat for six days, a breakaway region in the Eastern European country of Moldova is now short of electricity, too, with the authorities ordering eight hours of power cuts a day to prevent the overloaded electricity system from collapsing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Denying a Handshake to Harris, Senator’s Husband Draws Criticism
description: The husband of Senator Deb Fischer, Republican of Nebraska, drew criticism online when he failed to accept a handshake offered by Vice President Kamala D. Harris at his wife’s ceremonial swearing-in.
content: The ceremonial swearing-in of new senators is normally a perfunctory part of the start of a new Congress, a ritual orchestrated to showcase courtesy and camaraderie as even political rivals smile together for family photos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: Meta Says Fact-Checkers Were the Problem. Fact-Checkers Rule That False.
description: Fact-checking groups that worked with Meta said they had no role in deciding what the company did with the content that was fact-checked.
content: Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, blamed the company’s fact-checking partners for some of Facebook’s moderation issues, saying in a video that “fact-checkers have been too politically biased” and have “destroyed more trust than they created.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Kate Christobek and Wesley Parnell
title: Appeals Court Judge Refuses to Halt Trump’s New York Sentencing
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump is trying to expunge his conviction before he is inaugurated. He would be the first felon elected to the Oval Office.
content: A New York appellate court on Tuesday declined to halt President-elect Donald J. Trump’s criminal sentencing, damping his hopes of shutting down the case before returning to the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: What Is the U.K. ‘Grooming Gang’ Scandal Seized On by Elon Musk?
description: The billionaire tech mogul has been posting on his social media platform about a decade-old child sex abuse scandal in Britain. Here’s what to know.
content: Elon Musk, the billionaire tech mogul, has flung himself into British politics in recent weeks, using his social media platform X to attack and spread misinformation about Prime Minister Keir Starmer and other members of the Labour government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: They Met as Child Actors in ‘School of Rock.’ Now They’re Married.
description: Angelo Massagli and Caitlin Hale bonded as classmates in the 2003 Jack Black film. They brought the cast back together for their wedding.
content: Angelo Massagli and Caitlin Hale met as co-workers. They were 10 years old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan and Alan Feuer
title: Trump Again Hints at Jan. 6 Pardons, Including for Attacks on Police
description: At a news conference, the president-elect sought to blame the F.B.I. for the riot at the Capitol, echoing a conspiracy theory that is widespread on the right.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Tuesday once again left open the possibility of offering pardons to some of his supporters who are serving prison time for assaulting police officers during the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong and Charlie Cordero
title: The Panama Canal’s Newest Voyagers: Fishy Intruders From Two Oceans
description: A multibillion-dollar expansion helped the canal accommodate king-size cargo ships. It might also be fueling ecological upheaval.
content: Night fell as the two scientists got to work, unfurling long nets off the end of their boat. The jungle struck up its evening symphony: the sweet chittering of insects, the distant bellowing of monkeys, the occasional screech of a kite. Crocodiles lounged in the shallows, their eyes glinting when headlamps were shined their way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Burned Out? Start Here.
description: The self-help author Oliver Burkeman argues that the path to productivity — and peace of mind — begins with accepting your limitations.
content: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing to the show on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA Will Let Trump Decide How to Bring Mars Rocks to Earth
description: The Mars Sample Return effort was billions of dollars over budget and not expected to return to Earth with its samples until 2040.
content: NASA needs help fetching rocks from Mars, and on Tuesday, agency officials announced that they have not yet quite decided how to do that. Instead, they are leaving a final decision to the incoming administration of President-elect Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Man Charged in Subway Burning Says He Was Drunk and Remembers Nothing
description: Sebastian Zapeta-Calil, confronted with video of the immolation of Debrina Kawam, told detectives he was blackout drunk at the time. He pleaded not guilty to murder on Tuesday.
content: The man charged with burning a woman to death on the New York City subway last month told investigators that he did not remember the incident because he was blackout drunk at the time, according to a transcript of his interrogation released by prosecutors on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Mexico City to the Met: Frida Escobedo’s Supercharged Path to Fame
description: The 45-year-old architect had mostly designed temporary structures before becoming the first woman to design a wing at the country’s largest art museum.
content: Sometimes it can be hard to hear what Frida Escobedo is saying. She is reserved, restrained, a self-described introvert.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Who Are the Winners and Losers in Disney’s Fubo Deal?
description: The agreement ends litigation between the two companies over plans for a sports streaming service, but consumer advocates are pushing back.
content: Just a week into 2025, the media industry got its first consequential transaction: The Walt Disney Company is buying 70 percent of Fubo, the video service that had sued to block the media giant’s plan to create Venu, a sports streaming joint venture with Fox and Warner Bros. Discovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Hosts Appreciate an Uneventful Jan. 6
description: Jimmy Kimmel called Monday “the fourth anniversary of our Capitol being stormed by the Buffalo Wild Wing of the Republican Party.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Abortion Pills Prescribed by Pharmacists Are Newest Effort in Abortion Fight
description: Washington State’s program is the first, but other states are expected to try allowing pharmacists to prescribe the pills to counter growing efforts to curtail abortion access.
content: Pharmacists have begun prescribing abortion pills, not simply dispensing the medication — a development intended to broaden abortion access by taking advantage of rules that give them prescribing ability in most states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Theodore Schleifer
title: Meta to End Fact-Checking Program in Shift Ahead of Trump Term
description: The social networking giant will stop using third-party fact checkers and instead rely on users to add notes to posts. President-elect Trump and his conservative allies said they were pleased.
content: Meta said on Tuesday that it was ending its longstanding fact-checking program, a policy instituted to curtail the spread of misinformation across its social media apps, in a stark sign of how the company was repositioning itself for the Trump presidency and throwing its weight behind unfettered speech online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meaghan Tobin, Muyi Xiao and Amy Chang Chien
title: Taiwan Says It Suspects a Chinese-Linked Ship Damaged an Undersea Internet Cable
description: The Taiwanese Coast Guard said seven Chinese nationals were aboard a ship suspected of causing the damage.
content: Taiwan is investigating whether a ship linked to China is responsible for damaging one of the undersea cables that connects Taiwan to the internet, the latest reminder of how vulnerable Taiwan’s critical infrastructure is to damage from China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: How to Create a Compelling Collection: A Guide to Our New ‘My List’ Contest
description: Step-by-step instructions for coming up with an engaging list of recommendations for things we should — or shouldn’t — read, watch, experience, eat or listen to.
content: Are you participating in our new “My List” Review Contest? Given how much creative freedom it offers, we think it will be one of the most fun challenges we’re running this year. You can work alone or with others, and can choose from 14 categories — including music, TV, movies, video games, books, restaurants, theater and more — to make your list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Graff
title: Southern California Is Dangerously Dry for This Time of Year
description: Ordinarily, the region would have seen some rain by January.
content: Southern California is extremely dry right now, with huge portions of the region having seen less than a quarter-inch of rain in the last eight months. The landscape is parched and vegetation is withered, making the area dangerously susceptible to burning, an unusual situation for January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Laura Boushnak
title: At a Beloved Lebanese Market, the ‘Destruction Is Painful’
description: Israeli raids pummeled the historic souk in the city of Nabatieh, in southern Lebanon. Residents and shop owners are only beginning to come to terms with the damage.
content: The business owners arrived one by one, but all were united in their mission on a chilly December morning: Salvage anything from the pulverized market in this hillside city in southern Lebanon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Aldana Cohen and Thea Riofrancos
title: Biden Left Us With a ‘Prius Economy.’ It’s Time for Something Different.
description: Climate impacts are fueling the cost-of-living crisis, especially for the poor and working class.
content: In the lead-up to the November election, President-elect Donald Trump threatened to “terminate” President Biden’s signature climate law, the Inflation Reduction Act, calling it the “Green New Scam.” Whether or not he kills the law, he is committed to slowing America’s transition from fossil fuels to clean energy — and few Americans seem concerned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: 2 Prisoners Ask Judge to Block Biden’s Death Sentence Commutations
description: The men said that, by reducing their sentences to life in prison, President Biden’s act of clemency could hurt their appeals.
content: Two federal prisoners whose death sentences were recently commuted by President Biden have asked a judge to block the reduction in their sentences, arguing that it could jeopardize their appeals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Seo
title: How Sign Language Can Help Us All Be Better Communicators
description: The emotionality of ASL can free you from the trap of precision.
content: When I arrived on the second floor of a commercial building in Manhattan for my first sign-language class, a man took one look at my tentative posture and held up some fingers. One? Two? I put up one finger, and he shepherded me to the Level 1 class. It was disorienting: Class time was strictly “voices off,” to encourage immersive learning and to show respect to the teachers at the Sign Language Center, who are all deaf. Without the power of speech, all my classmates and I could do was smile and nod at one another, sitting in silence as we took in the new vocabulary (or “ASLary”) presented to us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Sweeney
title: Can Estrogen Cream Reverse Skin Aging?
description: Some cosmetics companies are marketing estrogen-infused face creams and serums to people in menopause. Do they work?
content: Q: I’ve seen several menopause-oriented brands selling anti-aging estrogen creams for the face. Is there any science behind them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton, Maggie Haberman and Alan Blinder
title: A Flurry of Announcements Signal That the Trump Family Will Keep Making Deals
description: Even before the start of the new administration, there has been repeated blurring of lines between the federal government efforts and Trump family businesses.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump was at the lectern talking through the approaching inauguration of his second term. But across the ballroom at his Mar-a-Lago resort in Palm Beach, Fla., was a display of the extraordinary way that his family business interests are now fully mixed with his plans for governance of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Elon Musk’s Dishonest Demagogy on Grooming Gangs
description: The billionaire is exploiting old atrocities to undermine his perceived enemies.
content: Over a decade ago, a horrific sex trafficking scandal rocked Britain. Starting in the late 1990s, thousands of mostly white girls in the postindustrial north of England, many from struggling families, were groomed by networks of mostly Pakistani men, who often professed to be their boyfriends before trapping them in a hell of repeated rape and prostitution. Several girls were murdered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen
title: What We Know About HMPV, the Virus Spreading in China
description: While cases are climbing in China, the situation is very different from what it was when Covid-19 emerged five years ago, medical experts say. HMPV is common and decades old.
content: Reports of a surge in cases of a respiratory virus in China have evoked dark echoes of the start of the Covid-19 pandemic almost exactly five years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Pippa Garner, Conceptual Artist With a Satirical Streak, Dies at 82
description: Her witty drawings, arresting sculptures and outlandish gadgets commented on consumerism, gender relations (she had transitioned), American car culture and more.
content: Pippa Garner, a conceptual art provocateur whose radically modified consumer goods — like a midriff-baring men’s “Half Suit” and a ’59 Chevy with its chassis reversed — offered witty commentary on gender, body modification, American car culture and the boundaries of fine art, died on Dec. 30 in Los Angeles. She was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Washington Kicks Off a Pomp-Filled Farewell to Carter, a Man of Humility
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, who once banned the playing of “Hail to the Chief,” will lie in state at the Capitol as part of three days of elaborate ceremonies.
content: The nation’s leaders on Tuesday kicked off three days of tributes to Jimmy Carter, staging an elaborate pageant of Washington fanfare for a politician who disavowed the trappings of the imperial presidency and never gave up his humble Georgia roots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: Trump Vowed Mass Deportations. Mexico and Central America Brace for Impact.
description: Donald J. Trump has said that Mexico is allowing an “invasion” of migrants into the United States. But the current situation on the ground tells a different story: Unlawful crossings at the U.S.-Mexico border dropped sharply last year.
content: Crossings into the United States from Mexico dropped sharply last year. But countries south of the U.S. border are waiting nervously to see if President-elect Donald J. Trump orders mass deportations.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Next Congress
description: We explore the disagreements that could define the new Congress — and potentially derail Donald Trump’s agenda.
content: Congress certified President-elect Donald Trump’s victory yesterday. Now that Republicans will hold the coveted “trifecta” — the White House, the Senate and the House — they’ll have their way in Washington, right? Maybe. The success of the Trump administration will hinge on congressional Republicans’ ability to stay united. It won’t be easy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz and Erin Griffith
title: A.I. Start-Up Anthropic Is in Talks That Could Value It at $60 Billion
description: The financing efforts follow new funding rounds by Elon Musk’s xAI and the market leader, OpenAI, which is now valued at $157 billion.
content: The San Francisco artificial intelligence start-up Anthropic is in talks to raise a new round of funding that could value the company at $60 billion, up from about $16 billion less than a year ago, according to two people with knowledge of the discussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Boris Fishman, Jillian Weinberger and Vishakha Darbha
title: There’s More to Wine Than Just a Cancer Warning
description: A wine aficionado argues that the surgeon general’s warning misses this type of alcohol’s complex joy.
content: Vivek Murthy, the surgeon general, recently recommended that cancer warnings be included on all alcohol products. The author and wine enthusiast Boris Fishman argues that doing so would place all forms of liquor in the same bucket — one that ignores the history, the generations of labor and the joy that accompany sipping a glass of wine. He’d like people “to think about this as just one example out of many in a life that risks becoming stripped of a certain kind of magic because we’re trying to protect ourselves out of existence.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Meta Turns to Community Notes, Mirroring X
description: Social media companies are abandoning years of fact-checking practices as Republicans criticize it as censorship.
content: Social media companies are increasingly relying on fact-checks written by their users, allowing companies to step back from politically loaded decisions about what content to take down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: Updating a 12th-Century Palazzo, Where the Walls Had Secrets
description: When two architects renovated the once-grand floor of a palace in Genoa, Italy, their goal wasn’t period perfection: “We didn’t want to live in a museum.”
content: Matteo Rocca and Ronan Dunphy peered into the gloom on the second floor of the 12th-century palazzo in Genoa, Italy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Sudanese Paramilitary Group Committed Genocide, U.S. Says
description: A force fighting Sudan’s army in a brutal civil war committed massacres and rape that amount to genocide, the Secretary of State said, two decades after a finding of genocide in the same region.
content: The United States on Tuesday accused a Sudanese paramilitary group and its proxies of committing genocide, singling them out in a conflict of unchecked brutality and drawing fresh attention to the scale of atrocities being perpetrated in Africa’s largest war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Boris Fishman
title: A Novel Unearths the Dark Secrets in a Ukrainian Coal Mine
description: “The Lady of the Mine,” by Sergei Lebedev, takes place during Russia’s 2014 invasion.
content: Don’t credit this review. It was assigned to me because I’m “Russian,” and so is the book in question, “The Lady of the Mine,” the sixth by the Russian novelist Sergei Lebedev. I was born in the U.S.S.R. and have devoted a part of my literary career to its concerns, so the idea is that I may be able to provide a more informed assessment of the book’s merits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: ‘One of the Faces of Jan. 6’
description: What happened to the rioter who put his boot on a desk in Nancy Pelosi’s office.
content: The photograph was an immediate symbol of Jan. 6, 2021: a man in bluejeans and a thick plaid overshirt reclining in the chambers of then-Speaker Nancy Pelosi, with a smile on his face and his boot resting atop a black spiral notebook on a corner of a desk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson, Berry Wang and Bhadra Sharma
title: Strong Earthquake Hits Remote Tibet in Western China, Killing Dozens
description: Chinese state media said at least 126 people had died in the magnitude 7.1 quake near an area of religious significance in Tibet. It was felt in neighboring Nepal.
content: Using their hands and shovels in frigid conditions, rescue workers dug through the rubble in the search for survivors after a deadly magnitude 7.1 earthquake toppled houses and jolted people awake in a remote part of Tibet on Tuesday near the northern foothills of Mount Everest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Brad Plumer
title: Trump Promises to End New Wind Farms
description: Wind energy is one of the fastest growing and cheapest forms of electricity in the United States. The president-elect calls it “garbage.”
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Tuesday that “no new windmills” would be built in the United States when he takes office, a direct rebuke of the Biden administration, which has approved 11 commercial-scale offshore wind projects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Sifferlin
title: America Needs a Norovirus Vaccine, Now
description: What better way to remind people of the power of vaccines than to eliminate the misery of vomiting?
content: It was the middle of the night, and my husband and I were taking turns trying to soothe our inconsolable 1-year-old. When the vomiting began, I remember thinking: So it’s come for us. A group chat of parents in our day care had warned that a stomach bug was spreading. The messages promised it would be brief and brutal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: Who Is Joel Kaplan, Meta’s New Global Policy Chief?
description: The longtime Republican lobbyist for Meta was named to the company’s top policy role last week.
content: Joel Kaplan, Meta’s new chief global affairs officer, played a leading role in Tuesday’s content moderation announcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Trump’s Return Is a Civil Society Failure
description: Is liberalism actually dead this time?
content: A key question emerging from the 2024 elections is whether the Democratic Party is significantly — or even permanently — wounded. Can it return to fighting trim in 2026 and 2028?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Syria’s Main Airport Handles First International Flights Since Fall of al-Assad
description: The country’s new leaders are pushing to restore a sense of normalcy. But Syria remains under a host of international sanctions imposed during the Assad regime.
content: Syria’s main airport handled its first international flights on Tuesday since the fall of the government of former President Bashar al-Assad last month, as the new leaders press to reassert a semblance of normalcy in the war-weary country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Los Angeles Fires Force Thousands to Evacuate
description: Also, Trump suggested expanding the U.S. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: Wildfires are spreading rapidly in Los Angeles, fanned by a fierce windstorm. Gusts of up to 100 m.p.h., stronger than any the region has seen in a decade, are forecast to blow through the night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick and Rebecca F. Elliott
title: Exxon Sues California Official, Claiming He Defamed the Company
description: The lawsuit, an unusual strategy for the oil giant, comes after California’s attorney general sued Exxon last year alleging it misled the public about plastics recycling.
content: Exxon Mobil sued California’s attorney general, the Sierra Club and other environmental groups on Monday, alleging that they conspired to defame the oil giant and kneecap its business prospects amid a debate over whether plastics can be recycled effectively.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Lauren Hirsch
title: Nvidia Bets Big on Robots
description: The chipmaker, which has led a  rally in artificial intelligence stocks, laid out a vision for dominating so-called physical A.I. Investors appeared impressed.
content: Heading into 2025, Nvidia was facing tough questions about whether the chipmaker central to the artificial intelligence boom could sustain its astronomical market run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: American Driver Is Fatally Shot by Police Officer in Mexico
description: The shooting in Ciudad Juárez was being investigated. A prosecutor said the driver, from Texas, had accelerated in the officer’s direction and nearly hit him.
content: An American man was killed when a Mexican police officer opened fire on the car he was driving in Ciudad Juárez, across the border from El Paso, Texas, the Mexican authorities said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Selig, Isabelle Taft and Soumya Karlamangla
title: ‘Get Back Up’: Biden Urges a New Round of Resilience for New Orleans
description: President Biden and the first lady joined a city already exhausted by disaster to remember the victims of a Jan. 1 terror attack on Bourbon Street.
content: The most famous street in New Orleans, lined with iron lace balconies and typically packed with tourists spilling from bars and jazz clubs, transformed into a crime scene on Jan. 1 when a man drove a pickup truck into crowds celebrating the dawn of the new year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: Tech Watchdogs Warn Meta’s Decision Could Cause Surge in Disinformation
description: While Republicans praised the move, some groups cautioned that effectively ending Meta’s fact-checking program would also lead to more conspiracy theories.
content: While Republicans largely cheered Meta’s announcement on Tuesday that it would effectively end its fact-checking program, several tech watchdog groups condemned the decision, warning of the potential for a surge in disinformation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Michael D. Shear
title: Trump Floats Using Force to Take Greenland and the Panama Canal
description: In an hourlong news conference at his Florida club, Mar-a-Lago, the president-elect delivered a hodgepodge of grievances, complaints and false claims.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump refused on Tuesday to rule out the use of military or economic coercion to force Panama to give up control of the canal that America built more than a century ago and to push Denmark to sell Greenland to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: Venezuelan Opposition Candidate Says His Son-in-Law Was Kidnapped
description: Edmundo González, who is recognized by the United States as the president-elect of Venezuela, said his son-in-law was kidnapped by hooded men.
content: The man widely called the true winner of Venezuela’s tainted presidential election said on Tuesday that his son-in-law had been kidnapped by hooded men in Caracas, the capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Golden Globes Audience Declines Slightly
description: The show on Sunday averaged 9.3 million viewers, down from 9.4 million the year before.
content: The Golden Globe Awards drew an average of 9.3 million viewers for CBS on Sunday night, a modest decline from last year, according to Nielsen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Catie Edmondson, Clare Toeniskoetter, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Rachelle Bonja, Rachel Quester, Liz O. Baylen, Daniel Powell, Marion Lozano, Pat McCusker, Elisheba Ittoop and Alyssa Moxley
title: Republicans Take Control of Congress — and Harris Certifies Her Own Loss
description: The new Congress certified the 2024 election results without any contest.
content: During their first few days in power, the Republican-controlled House and Senate vowed to put aside their furious intraparty battles to make Donald J. Trump’s sweeping agenda the law of the land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Ireland Joins South Africa’s Genocide Case Against Israel
description: Ireland had said it would intervene in the case at the International Court of Justice, arguing that Israel’s actions in Gaza amounted to collective punishment.
content: Ireland has formally joined South Africa’s genocide case against Israel, according to a statement on Tuesday from the International Court of Justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: Close-Up Magic Gets an Up-Close Venue in Brooklyn
description: 69 Atlantic hosts weekly shows by the world’s best magicians in a suitably intimate setting.
content: One recent Friday night, a hidden door at the rear of Art of Play, a curiosity shop in Brooklyn Heights, swung open and theatrical smoke wafted into the store. Two dozen people had been waiting for this moment, passing the time by handling the store’s menagerie of optical illusions, wooden puzzles and magic-adjacent objects. Now, they filed through a short passageway and into a tiny room with three rows of benches and standing room for a few people in the back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Bob Dylan Wasn’t the Only 1965 Newport Highlight. Hear 14 More.
description: Listen to Peter, Paul and Mary’s finale singalong, plus songs from Odetta, the Paul Butterfield Blues Band and more.
content: Jon Pareles here, chief pop critic at The Times, sitting in for Lindsay. With pop in its early January lull, let’s dive into some history that’s now being rediscovered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner and Justin Porter
title: Wednesday Briefing: Meta Set to End Fact-Checking
description: Plus, 52 places to go this year
content: Meta will stop using third-party fact-checkers on Facebook, Threads and Instagram. It will instead rely on users to add notes to posts that may be false or misleading, similar to a system used on X. Follow our live coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: In Israeli Video, Detainee Says Hamas Operates Out of Gaza Hospital
description: Facing international condemnation and pressure to free the chief of Kamal Adwan Hospital, Israel released a brief interrogation video backing up its claim that militants used the hospital as a base.
content: As international condemnation mounts over the Israeli military’s arrest late last month of the director of Kamal Adwan Hospital in northern Gaza, the Israeli military said on Tuesday that it had new evidence that militant groups had used the hospital as a command center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Farber
title: Peter Yarrow, the Peter of Peter, Paul and Mary, Dies at 86
description: The folk trio he formed with Noel Paul Stookey and Mary Travers became a pop phenomenon, scoring hits like “If I Had a Hammer” and “Puff the Magic Dragon.”
content: Peter Yarrow, whose caring and righteous vocals for the trio Peter, Paul and Mary helped establish them as one of the most popular folk acts of the 1960s, died on Tuesday at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Your 2025 Most-Anticipated List
description: What are you looking forward to this year?
content: What’s coming up this year that you’re excited about? An important birthday, celebration or milestone? A trip you’re planning to take? A friend who is coming to visit? A class you’re taking? Something you plan to build, make or create? A TV show or movie that’s coming out soon?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: House Passes Bill to Deport Unauthorized Immigrants Charged With Minor Crimes
description: Forty-eight Democrats joined Republicans in supporting legislation that aims to deport more migrants charged with nonviolent crimes, a first salvo in a broader crackdown.
content: The House passed a bill on Tuesday that would target undocumented immigrants charged with nonviolent crimes for deportation, an opening salvo from a Republican majority that has vowed to deliver on President-elect Donald J. Trump’s promised crackdown at the border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Holmes
title: Happily Married, Politically at Peace. Until a Run for Congress Gets in the Way.
description: In her lively debut novel, “How to Sleep at Night,” Elizabeth Harris measures what happens when the Republican half of a gay couple dials up the campaign rhetoric.
content: The witty opening of Elizabeth Harris’s “How to Sleep at Night” finds Ethan Keller confessing “something terrible” to his husband, Gabe: He wants to run for Congress. Ethan is a Republican, but Gabe is a Democrat, and Ethan says he won’t run if Gabe says no. Wanting to support his husband’s dreams and fearing the resentment a refusal could bring, Gabe agrees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
title: Judge Cannon Blocks Release of Special Counsel’s Final Report on Trump
description: Judge Aileen M. Cannon, a Trump appointee who had dismissed the documents case in its entirety, temporarily barred the Justice Department from releasing Jack Smith’s account of his investigation.
content: The federal judge who handled President-elect Donald J. Trump’s prosecution on charges of mishandling classified documents temporarily barred the Justice Department on Tuesday from releasing a final report about the case by the special counsel, Jack Smith.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Congestion Pricing, Day 2: A Period of Adjustment
description: Some people were irate, others were pleased, as New Yorkers faced a new toll on driving into the center of Manhattan.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday, the second day of a workweek that loomed as the first real test of congestion pricing. We’ll find out how the toll program is doing. We’ll also get details on the crime rate, which fell last year — but felony assaults rose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Do Football Fans Really Want to Be Fashionable?
description: Emma Grede of Skims and Good American and Kristin Juszczyk say the answer is yes.
content: Almost exactly a year ago, Kristin Juszczyk, the wife of the San Francisco 49ers fullback Kyle Juszczyk, who had been happily D.I.Y.-ing her own game-day merch, became the Cinderella of her own fashion fairy tale when Taylor Swift wore one of Ms. Juszczyk’s custom-made jackets to watch her new boyfriend, Travis Kelce, play football. Before you could say touchdown, she had 1.2 million Instagram followers, a licensing deal with the N.F.L. and was chosen to make a jacket for the winner of the Indy 500.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: What Will Power the A.I. Revolution?
description: The energy that will power the booming data-center industry could end up increasing emissions, at least in the short term.
content: Last week, Microsoft announced that it would spend approximately $80 billion during this fiscal year to build data centers for its booming artificial intelligence business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: #MeToo Theater Campaigners Stage a Drama of Their Own
description: The French activists behind the hashtag #MeTooThéâtre have devised a play that shows the personal cost of bringing abuse claims to light.
content: In 2021, the hashtag #MeTooThéâtre began trending on social media in France. Thousands of stories about sexual abuse and harassment in the country’s theaters and drama schools poured in. Calls for change followed, starting with an open letter signed by 1,450 public figures in the newspaper Libération.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Defense Lawyers Seek to Block Special Counsel Report in Trump Documents Case
description: Both the Justice Department and the judge who oversaw the case were asked to stop the public release of the report.
content: Defense lawyers asked both the Justice Department and a federal judge on Monday night to stop the special counsel, Jack Smith, from publicly releasing a report detailing his investigation into President-elect Donald J. Trump’s mishandling of classified documents after he left office in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devlin Barrett
title: Report Faults Trump Officials Over Coronavirus Inquiry in New York and New Jersey
description: While the findings are dated, they come as many current and former Justice Department officials fear that the incoming Trump administration will run the department with an eye toward score-settling.
content: Three senior Trump administration officials violated Justice Department rules just before the 2020 election by divulging details of an investigation into coronavirus deaths at nursing homes in New York and other Democratic-run states, according to an inspector general document obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Brad Plumer
title: A Key Part of Biden’s Climate Law Was Built to Survive Trump. Now, the Test.
description: A lucrative tax credit for renewable energy could be hard to kill because it applies to a technologies favored by Republicans, not just wind and solar.
content: One of the most powerful parts of President Biden’s signature climate law was designed to attract support from such a wide array of industries that it would be hard for Congress to repeal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: 2 Bodies Found in JetBlue Plane’s Landing Gear at Fort Lauderdale Airport
description: A routine post-flight inspection revealed two bodies in the landing gear compartment of a JetBlue plane after a flight from New York on Monday, the airline said.
content: Two bodies were discovered in the landing gear compartment of a JetBlue plane on Monday after a flight from New York to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., the airline said in a statement on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Celebrities Flee Their Homes as Fire Forces More Evacuations
description: Some residents shared photos of the smoke and flames enveloping Pacific Palisades. One actor jumped in to help with the evacuation effort.
content: As strong winds spread the Pacific Palisades fire on Tuesday afternoon, the residents of some of the region’s mansions and desirable homes were forced to evacuate, including some well-known actors and people who work in the entertainment industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton and Alan Blinder
title: Saudi-Backed LIV Golf Will Return to Trump’s Doral Resort in 2025
description: The April event will be the first in which the Saudi-financed tournament will occur at a Trump location while Donald J. Trump is president.
content: The Saudi-backed LIV Golf league announced Tuesday that it would return to the Trump family’s Doral resort in April, the clearest sign yet that Trump family business deals using Saudi government financing will continue into the new presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump is expected to hold his second news conference since winning the election.
description: The expected topic is an economic development, b
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump is expected to hold his second news conference since winning the election in November on Tuesday morning at his Florida residence and club, Mar-a-Lago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: With Trump Coveting Greenland, Denmark Updated Its Coat of Arms
description: Before President-elect Donald Trump’s latest remarks, King Frederik X signaled his commitment to the territory in a decidedly old-fashioned way.
content: Over the last month, President-elect Donald J. Trump has repeatedly discussed his desire for the United States to purchase Greenland, and during a long news conference on Tuesday he refused to rule out using military force to accomplish that goal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher, Jon Caramanica and Stella Bugbee
title: Are These Shoes Hideous or Genius?
description: A conversation about the New Balance “Snoafers” — not quite sneakers, not quite loafers.
content: Some shoes we simply wear. Others, we debate endlessly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: A Sluggish Start for Congestion Pricing
description: It would be more effective if Ubers, taxis and trucks had to pay more.
content: On its third day, New York City’s congestion pricing system isn’t going as well as hoped, but it’s still a good idea and it can be improved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Bryn Terfel, Suave and Thundering, Is Back at the Met After 13 Years
description: The booming bass-baritone stars in Puccini’s “Tosca” after ill-timed injuries kept him away from the Metropolitan Opera, where he was a perennial favorite.
content: Few operatic cat-and-mouse games are as dramatic as the confrontation in Puccini’s “Tosca” between the innocent title character and Scarpia, the brutal chief of the Roman police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Slagle
title: Greens, Beans and Grains: Assemble
description: The mighty three ingredients that save my weeknight dinners (and a new habit-forming technique for cooking them easily).
content: Hi, everyone!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Trump’s Pick for U.S. Attorney Is Enmeshed in Long Island Politics
description: Joseph Nocella Jr. has maintained deep connections in a Republican Party organization that has veered sharply to the right.
content: As a district court judge on Long Island, Joseph Nocella Jr. presided over low-level criminal cases and disputes involving small amounts of money. He could soon oversee some of the country’s highest-profile criminal cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: Can San Francisco’s New Mayor Make the City Shine Again?
description: Daniel Lurie, an heir to the Levi Strauss fortune, will soon take the helm of the liberal mecca. “Resistance” to Donald Trump isn’t on his agenda.
content: Daniel Lurie, San Francisco’s mayor-elect, beckoned them, one by one, to his four-story brick mansion, perched on a hill, in the city’s exclusive Pacific Heights neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nazaneen Ghaffar and Judson Jones
title: The South Braces for a Potentially Disruptive Round of Snow and Ice
description: Just after the season’s first major winter storm, snow and ice are set to sweep across Texas and into the Carolinas this week.
content: With arctic air still locked in place across the East, the next winter storm is poised to bring a treacherous mix of snow, sleet, ice and freezing rain to the South and possibly the Mid-Atlantic, which once again could potentially disrupt travel and daily life for millions of people in the coming days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Firefighter Is Killed After Roof Partly Collapses in Honolulu Blaze
description: Five other people, including four firefighters, were taken to the hospital with injuries from the fire.
content: A firefighter died and five people were injured on Monday after flames engulfed a building in Honolulu and caused the roof to partly collapse, the authorities in Hawaii said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann
title: For Many Returning Russian Veterans, a Long Road of Recovery Awaits
description: A large number of soldiers return as amputees, and many suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder. Once home, they face stigma and a grueling course of rehabilitation.
content: Aleksandr had only two weeks of training in Russia before being sent to the front lines in Ukraine in the summer of 2023. About a month later, he became an amputee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Virginia Holds the First Elections of the New Trump Era
description: Voters are going to the polls on Tuesday in three special elections for the legislature that will serve as barometers of political energy for both parties.
content: The first special elections since President-elect Donald J. Trump won a second term are arriving on Tuesday in Virginia, where voters in three races will determine the majorities in the state’s legislature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Justin Trudeau’s Trying to Save His Party. Is He Hurting Canada?
description: By suspending Parliament and promising to resign, the prime minister bought the Liberals time. But Canada will now face Donald J. Trump with a lame duck in charge.
content: Justin Trudeau’s announcement on Monday that he would resign was the last card that Canada’s deeply unpopular prime minister, who had set his party on course to lose a national election, had left to play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden to Designate Chuckwalla and Sáttítla National Monuments in California
description: With these two new monuments, Mr. Biden has protected more federal land and waters than any other president, about 674 million acres.
content: President Biden will travel on Tuesday to the Coachella Valley in California to announce the creation of two national monuments that together will protect more than 848,000 acres of land in the state from drilling and mining as well as wind, solar and other energy development.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Day 2: Are Ultraprocessed Foods Really That Delicious?
description: Today’s challenge involves using the five senses.
content: This is Day 2 of the 5-Day Healthier Eating Challenge. To start at the beginning, click here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Sampson
title: Disaster by the Numbers: The Crisis in Sudan
description: The United States just formally declared that genocide has taken place in the northeast African nation, but the calamity there dates back decades.
content: A civil war in Sudan that has killed 150,000 people and forced more than 11 million others from their homes, by some estimates, prompted the U.S. government on Tuesday to declare that a genocide had been perpetrated by one of the war’s main antagonists, the ethnic Arab militia known as the Rapid Support Forces.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 7, 2025
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Jan. 7, 2025.
content: An article on Sunday about the recipients of the Presidential Medal of Freedom misstated which child of Robert F. Kennedy’s accepted the medal on his behalf. It was Kerry Kennedy, not Kathleen Kennedy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Valerie Hopkins, David Zucchino, Robert Jimison, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Justin Trudeau to Resign, and U.S. Reports First Bird Flu Death
description: Plus, the Taliban welcome tourists to Afghanistan.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brendan Borrell
title: Drug Company to Share Revenues With Indigenous People Who Donated Their Genes
description: Variant Bio, a small biotech company based in Seattle, is using genetic information from Indigenous people to develop drugs for obesity and diabetes.
content: When Stephane Castel first met with a group of Māori people and other Pacific Islanders in New Zealand to talk about his drug company’s plans for genetic research, locals worried he might be seeking to profit from the genes of community members without much thought to them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Justin Trudeau will step down as Canada’s prime minister.
content: Justin Trudeau, who has served as Canada’s prime minister for almost a decade, said that he would step down in the coming months, bowing to an angry electorate at a time of uncertain economic prospects and political infighting. He has suspended Parliament until March 24, he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Pentagon Reaches Settlement With Veterans Dismissed Over Sexuality
description: The agreement, if approved by a judge, would let former service members upgrade their discharge status and receive benefits they had been denied.
content: The Defense Department has reached a sweeping settlement with tens of thousands of people who were dismissed from military service because of their sexual identity, potentially paving the way for veterans to upgrade their discharge status and receive a range of benefits they had been denied.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Assessing Trump’s Florida News Conference
description: The president-elect made inaccurate claims about his predecessor’s energy policies and repeated familiar falsehoods on a number of topics.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump, in a news conference on Tuesday from his private club and residence in Florida, repeatedly denounced President Biden and made a series of inaccurate claims about energy policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Pittsburgh Man Who Threw an Explosive at University Police Gets 5 Years
description: Brian DiPippa was accused of dropping smoke bomb containers at a University of Pittsburgh campus transgender rights protest in 2023. His wife, Krystal DiPippa, was sentenced to probation.
content: A federal judge on Monday sentenced a Pittsburgh man to five years in prison and his wife to three years of probation over their involvement in detonating an explosive that injured police officers at a 2023 campus protest over transgender rights at the University of Pittsburgh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: febrile
description: This word has appeared in 26 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word febrile has appeared in 26 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 20 in “The Disease Detectives Trying to Keep the World Safe From Bird Flu” by Stephanie Nolen:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: The Voice of South Africa’s First Post-Apartheid Generation
description: Thandiswa Mazwai has sung of South Africa’s highs and lows since the country became a multiracial democracy 30 years ago. “My calling is to sing the people’s joy, to sing the people’s sadness.”
content: At a gala dinner held soon after South Africa’s most contested election since the end of apartheid, a singer reminded the gathered politicians how to do their jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Cafe Commerce Marks the Uptown Revival of a Downtown Staple
description: Mango Bay serves twists on Caribbean fare, Bananas offers creative takes on Asian dishes and more restaurant news.
content: Though closed for nearly a decade, Commerce in the West Village has been reconfigured on the Upper East Side by Harold Moore, its former executive chef and co-owner. Warmly lit, the 55-seat bistro now leans Art Deco without insisting; an oblong mural by David Joel from the downtown spot, hangs over the bar. Mr. Moore, steeped in the French idiom after working with Jean-Georges Vongerichten and Daniel Boulud, serves roast chicken with foie gras stuffing, stretching the budget at $99, one of several dishes for two. Farther afield are chicken schnitzel, steak Diane and a towering coconut cake. Regulars at Charlie Palmer restaurants might recognize the general manager, Charles Pouchot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Peter Yarrow Bridged Folk-Pop Eras
description: With Peter, Paul and Mary, the musician, who died on Tuesday at 86, eased folk songs into the Top 10.
content: Near the end of “A Complete Unknown,” the Bob Dylan biopic that centers on his move into rock in 1965, an earnest, slim, bearded, clearly nervous M.C. struggles to pacify a wildly divided crowd that has just heard Dylan sing three plugged-in songs at the Newport Folk Festival. Boomers will immediately recognize that M.C. as Peter Yarrow, himself a festival headliner in the folk-revival trio Peter, Paul and Mary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel and Mike Isaac
title: Mark Zuckerberg’s Political Evolution, From Apologies to No More Apologies
description: Meta’s chief executive has stepped away from his mea culpa approach to issues on his platforms and has told people that he wants to return to his original thinking on free speech.
content: In November 2016, as Facebook was being blamed for a torrent of fake news and conspiracy theories swirling around the first election of Donald J. Trump, Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of the social network, wrote an apologetic post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Green
title: I’m the Governor of Hawaii. I’ve Seen What Vaccine Skepticism Can Do.
description: Before I was governor of Hawaii, I saw how Robert F. Kennedy Jr. contributed to a measles outbreak in Samoa.
content: In early December 2019, I called Faimalotoa Kika Stowers, the health minister of Samoa. The measles outbreak that began earlier that fall on her small Pacific island nation had spread out of control and become an epidemic that threatened to overwhelm the country. The deep bond Hawaii shares with Samoa meant this was a shared crisis. As the lieutenant governor of Hawaii at the time and a practicing physician, I knew we needed to act quickly to save lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg and Annie Correal
title: Gunman at Honduran Consulate in Georgia Kills One and Injures Another
description: A gunman tried to enter the consulate with a weapon, and then opened fire outside the entrance to the building, officials said.
content: A gunman was arrested after killing a security guard and injuring another person outside the Honduran consulate near Atlanta on Monday afternoon, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Meta Drops Rules Protecting L.G.B.T.Q. Community as Part of Content Moderation Overhaul
description: The changes included allowing users to share “allegations of mental illness or abnormality when based on gender or sexual orientation.”
content: For years, social media companies made it a top priority to combat hate speech. But in recent months, they have waffled over how to tackle hateful online commentary, particularly when it is directed at L.G.B.T.Q. communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Disordered State
description: Dana Edwards makes a stylish second appearance in the New York Times Crossword.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Atossa Araxia Abrahamian
title: A Fugitive Businessman, Done In by One Law He Couldn’t Dodge
description: Fleeing fraud charges, Samuele Landi evaded extradition treaties, dabbled in crypto, procured diplomatic credentials and took advantage of all the offshore world has to offer.
content: Around midday on Feb. 2, a large wave began its slow rumble toward the Aisland 1, an 800-ton deck barge floating in the waters between Dubai and Iran. On board the vessel were its residents of more than a year: a 58-year-old Italian businessman named Samuele Landi, three sailors, a cook and five cats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: What Can You Recommend?
description: If you were to make a list of the music, movies, TV, books, video games, fashion, tech or restaurants others should know about — or avoid — what would you put on it?
content: What were the best songs of 2024?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Biden Administration Moves to Ban Medical Debt From Credit Reports
description: The future of the new rule remains in question, however, with President-elect Donald J. Trump set to return to the White House this month.
content: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau moved on Tuesday to ban medical debt from appearing on credit reports, potentially lifting the credit scores of about 15 million Americans and making it easier for them to obtain loans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Michael Crowley
title: Trump Warns ‘All Hell Will Break Out’ if Hostages in Gaza Are Not Freed
description: The president-elect did not elaborate on what actions he might take if the captives are not released by the time he takes office.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Tuesday that “all hell will break out in the Middle East” if the hostages being held by Hamas are not released by Inauguration Day, repeating the threat four times during a wide-ranging news conference at his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: What if ICE Agents Show Up? Schools Prepare Teachers and Parents.
description: Across the country, educators described widespread anxiety about President-elect Donald J. Trump’s promises to deport immigrants and what it could mean for their students.
content: If immigration agents arrive on the doorstep of a New York City public school, principals have been told what to do. Ask the officers to wait outside, and call a school district lawyer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Washington Post Lays Off 4% of Its Work Force
description: The layoffs will affect employees across The Post’s business operations, not its newsroom.
content: The Washington Post has started laying off roughly 4 percent of its work force, the company said on Tuesday, as the newspaper struggles to stem millions of dollars in annual losses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Minho Kim
title: Why Does Trump Want Greenland?
description: The president-elect said the United States needed the island, which is a semiautonomous part of Denmark, for national security reasons. But there are other possible interests.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s attention returned Tuesday to an idea that has fascinated him for years: acquiring Greenland for the United States. In a news conference on Tuesday, he refused to rule out using military or economic force to take the territory from Denmark, a U.S. ally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The Biden Presidency: Four Illusions, Four Deceptions
description: History will not remember his term of office fondly.
content: Americans tend to have a soft spot for our former presidents. Even the bad ones.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Opening Religion to Artificial Intelligence
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 7, 2025.
content: “Just as the Torah instructs us to love our neighbors as ourselves, can we also extend this love and empathy to the A.I. entities we create?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Carol Rosenberg
title: U.S. Presses for Release of Americans Held in Afghanistan
description: The White House has discussed a possible swap with the Taliban for a prisoner at Guantánamo Bay, according to people familiar with the matter.
content: U.S. officials made a new offer to the Taliban over the weekend to try to secure the release of Americans held in Afghanistan, according to people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,299
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Jan. 8, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Are Youth Sports Too Stressful to Be Fun Anymore?
description: The N.B.A. superstar Luka Doncic wants to make youth basketball joyful again. How do you think that could be done for organized sports?
content: Have you ever participated in organized sports, in or out of school? If so, have those experiences been positive? Or do you feel that youth sports have become too stressful and too focused on winning?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 577
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Jan. 8, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Patti Davis’s Reflections on Joe Biden and Her Dad, Ronald Reagan
description: Readers discuss a guest essay about the aging of two presidents. Also: A peaceful Jan. 6; the Palestinians’ future; mind-altering drugs.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Virginia State Legislature Special Election Results

title: Read Defense Lawyers’ Arguments to Block a Trump Documents Case Report
description: Lawyers for President-elect Donald J. Trump urged the attorney general in a letter to stop the special counsel from publicly releasing a final report on the case, while lawyers for his co-defendants, in a court filing, asked the same of the judge who oversaw the case.

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Claire Hogan
title: What Trudeau’s Resignation Means for Canada
description: By suspending Parliament and promising to resign, the prime minister bought the Liberals time. But Canada will now face Donald Trump with a lame duck in charge.
content: By suspending Parliament and promising to resign, the prime minister bought the Liberals time. But Canada will now face Donald Trump with a lame duck in charge.

author: By Jancee Dunn and Theodore Tae
title: Happier, Healthier Eating
description: Why don’t Cheetos taste like cheese? As part of The Times’s January Challenge, Well columnist Jancee Dunn and flavor scientist Dr. Arielle Johnson investigate why ultraprocessed foods differ so much from their whole food counterparts — and why they can be addictive.

author: By Tariro Mzezewa, Christina Shaman, Karen Hanley, James Surdam and Ray Jones
title: Our 52 Places to Go Lists Show How Travel Has Changed Over 20 Years
description: When The New York Times’s 52 Places to Go list made its debut in 2005, world travelers had no smartphones, no Instagram and no Google Maps. As the list turns 20 years old, our reporter Tariro Mzezewa gives insight into how travel has changed in the last two decades.
content: When The New York Times’s 52 Places to Go list made its debut in 2005, world travelers had no smartphones, no Instagram and no Google Maps. As the list turns 20 years old, our reporter Tariro Mzezewa gives insight into how travel has changed in the last two decades.

author: By The New York Times
title: Trump Suggests U.S. Expansion Into Greenland and Canada
description: During a news conference at Mar-a-Lago on Tuesday, President-elect Donald J. Trump refused to rule out using military force to retake the Panama Canal.
